data.name: ChoiceOfAlgorithmToolTop
data.value: At this point one of the ciphers contained in the list can be selected. This cipher can be examined by differential cryptanalysis.

data.name: Cipher1
data.value: Tutorial 1: Cipher 1 (16 bit blocksize, 2 subkeys, keylength is 32 bit)

data.name: Cipher2
data.value: Tutorial 2: Cipher 2 (16 bit blocksize, 4 subkeys, keylength is 64 bit)

data.name: Cipher3
data.value: Tutorial 3: Cipher 3 (16 bit blocksize, 6 subkeys, keylength is 96 bit)

data.name: Cipher4
data.value: Tutorial 4: Cipher 4 (4 bit blocksize, 4 subkeys, keylength is16 bit)

data.name: DescriptionContent1
data.value: The following is a short description of the ciphers of the individual parts of the tutorial:

data.name: DescriptionContent2
data.value: Tutorial 1 uses cipher 1 of the ToyChiffren component. This cipher works on 16 bit blocks and uses two round keys. One encryption round is executed. In this tutorial two unknown 16 bit round keys are restored.

data.name: DescriptionContent3
data.value: Tutorial 2 uses cipher 2 of the ToyChiffren component. This cipher works on 16 bit blocks and uses four round keys. Three encryption rounds are executed. In this tutorial four unknown 16 bit roundkeys are restored.

data.name: DescriptionContent4
data.value: Tutorial 3 uses cipher 3 of the ToyChiffren component. This cipher works on 16 bit blocks and uses six round keys. Five encryption rounds are executed. In this tutorial six unknown 16 bit round keys are restored.

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content2Run1
data.value: is already known. The cryptoanalyst now tries all values t of k

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content3Run1
data.value: is valid, t is noted as a candidate for k

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content3Run3
data.value: . If more than one candidate remains at the end, the attack will be reshuffled with new pairs of plaintext and ciphertext.

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide10Content4
data.value: By clicking the "next" button again, differential cryptanalysis can be performed on cipher 1 in the "Key Recovery" component.

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content1
data.value: At this point we apply the idea of differential cryptanalysis to cipher 1. The structure of a cipher is usually public, so that all components and their functionality are known. The security of a cipher should never be based on the secrecy of the construction, but on the secrecy of the key. This requirement is also called Kerckhoffs' principle.

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content2Run1
data.value: Cipher 1 consists of key addition and substitution. The structure can be viewed in the ToyCipher component. We now try to restore the two unknown round keys k

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content2Run5
data.value: . To do this, we first look at the individual steps of the encryption. First, a key addition to the input block is performed with k

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide1Content3
data.value: Subsequently, a substitution by the SBoxes takes place:

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide2Content1Run1
data.value: Finally, a key addition with k

data.value: The following figure summarizes the encryption process as outlined above:

data.value: The cryptoanalyst knows the parameters m and c, but the internal intermediate values u and v are unknown, as k

data.name: DifferentialCryptanalysisSlide9Content1Run5
data.value: are unknown. However, the cryptanalyst knows the difference between the internal values. In the following, we look at two messages m

data.value: and perform the encryption process partially:

data.value: This knowledge can be used to get k

data.name: ExpectedDifferentialToolTip
data.value: This difference describes the expected value that should occur with a high probability at the previously specified position ( round, SBox).

data.name: IntroductionSlide1Content1
data.value: In this section we consider the basic idea of differential cryptanalysis. Many symmetric round-based block ciphers consist of three basic operations: Key addition, substitution and permutation. In this section, we limit ourselves to key addition and substitution.

data.name: IntroductionSlide1Content2
data.value: Many ciphers use the XOR operation (exclusive-OR) for key addition. The XOR operation is a two-digit operator that can be described by the following value table:

data.name: IntroductionSlide2Content1
data.value: If the XOR operation is performed with a message m and key k, the ciphertext is generated:

data.name: IntroductionSlide2Content2
data.value: The core idea of differential cryptanalysis is now to use the key twice. Let's look at the impact at this point:

data.name: IntroductionSlide2Content3
data.value: We get back the original message m. The XOR operation is often referred to as the difference operator. This is what we will do in this tutorial.

data.name: IntroductionSlide2Content4
data.value: In reality, ciphers are more extensive, more complicated and do not consist exclusively of key additions. The differential cryptanalysis is a so called "chosen plaintext attack", which means the cryptanalyst can select plaintext messages and encrypt them to have matching plaintext/ciphertext pairs.

data.name: IntroductionSlide3Content1
data.value: We take advantage of the idea of using the key twice by looking at pairs of messages. Then the following can be calculated:

data.name: IntroductionSlide3Content3
data.value: In words, we get the difference of the plain texts by calculating the difference of the key texts.

data.name: MessageCountToolTip
data.value: Number of messages the oracle should generate

data.name: OverviewContent1
data.value: Welcome to the differential cryptanalysis tutorial. This method for the analysis of round-based symmetric block ciphers aims at recovering single bits up to complete round keys. This method was published in 1991 by the two Israeli researchers, Eli Biham and Adi Shamir.

data.name: OverviewContent2
data.value: This tutorial describes the differential cryptanalysis (DCA) procedure in three parts. Part 1 explains the basic idea of DCA using a cipher with one encryption round. Part 2 deepens this idea using a cipher with three encryption rounds. Part three deepens the knowledge by increasing the complexity of the cipher to 5 encryption rounds. In part three the knowledge is deepened by increasing the complexity of the cipher to 5 encryption rounds.

data.name: OverviewContent3
data.value: In the configuration of this component the different parts of the tutorial can be selected.

data.name: OverviewContent4
data.value: Have fun trying out and breaking the ciphers!

data.name: OverviewContent5
data.value: (This introduction can be skipped by starting the workspace)

data.name: PathToolTip
data.value: These values describe the flow of the difference values through a cipher.

data.name: PluginTooltip
data.value: The DCA PathFinder component searches for differentials in a symmetric block cipher depending on parameters specified by the user.

data.name: PresentationModeToolTip
data.value: If tutorial mode is activated, a presentation with information on differential cryptanalysis is made for each tutorial

data.name: StartMaskContent1
data.value: The tutorial starts when you start the workspace.

data.name: TitleHeader
data.value: Tutorial differential cryptanalysis of symmetric block ciphers
